criteria: Expressing Sums with a Common Factor
descriptions: Student is unable to identify any common factors between two numbers.
Student can identify some common factors, but not the greatest common factor.
Student can identify the GCF of simple number pairs (e.g., single-digit numbers) but struggles with larger numbers.
Student can identify the GCF of most number pairs up to 100 but makes occasional errors.
Student consistently and accurately identifies the GCF of number pairs up to 100.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of GCF and can explain the process of finding the GCF for numbers beyond 100.
Student is unable to identify any common multiples between two numbers.
Student can identify some common multiples, but not the least common multiple.
Student can identify the LCM of simple number pairs (e.g., single-digit numbers) but struggles with the number constraints.
Student can identify the LCM of most number pairs up to 12 but makes occasional errors.
Student consistently and accurately identifies the LCM of number pairs up to 12.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of LCM and can explain the process of finding the LCM for numbers beyond 12.
Student does not demonstrate any understanding of the distributive property.
Student attempts to use the distributive property but makes significant errors in application.
Student can apply the distributive property to simple expressions but struggles with more complex expressions or larger numbers.
Student can apply the distributive property to most expressions with numbers up to 100 but makes occasional errors.
Student consistently and accurately applies the distributive property to express sums with a common factor.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of the distributive property and can apply it creatively in various problem-solving scenarios.
Student is unable to express sums with a common factor.
Student attempts to express sums, but does not correctly identify or factor out the greatest common factor.
Student can express sums with a common factor for simple expressions but struggles with more complex expressions.
Student can express most sums with a common factor, but has trouble reducing the expression to numbers with no common factor.
Student can express sums with a common factor, and reduce the expression to numbers with no common factor.
Student can express sums with a common factor for both simple and complex expressions.
